title: Rare $4 Gold Coin Could Be Worth $200,000
text:
A $4 gold coin from 1879 will be auctioned at the Whitman Baltimore Winter Expo in Baltimore, Md., on Nov. 14.

Text size

A gold U.S. coin with a denomination of four dollars that was originally intended to be used as a world currency could fetch $200,000 when it is auctioned at the Whitman Baltimore Winter Expo in Baltimore, Md., on Nov. 14.

Known as the $4 Gold Stella, the 1879 coin was designed to weigh and compose precious metals that match the Latin Monetary Union, which unified several European currencies into a single currency.

It was established in 1865 among Belgium, France, Italy, and Switzerland, and was joined by many other continental European nations. Through the Union, one franc would worth be the same amount as one lira, peseta, leva, or drachma, and be easily exchangeable within the member nations. The Union was dissolved in 1927.

A $4 coin was proposed by Congressman John Kasson of Iowa, who was appointed by President Rutherford B. Hayes as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to the Austro-Hungarian Empire in 1877. While there, he experienced difficulties in converting American dollars into Austrian florins and back again. Upon his return to the U.S., he submitted a proposal for a $4 coin that would be closer in weight to the Austro-Hungarian 8 florin piece, which was equivalent to the French 20 franc coin.

The back of $4 coin Courtesy of Stack's Bowers Galleries

Two designs were prepared, one featuring Flowing Hair by Charles E. Barber, and the other featuring Coiled Hair design by George T. Morgan. Barber's Flowing Hair design was the first selected for production and an estimated 25—some estimate as few as 10 to 15—were distributed to Congress leaders.

In 1880, the Mint struck more examples, estimated to be in the region of between 425 to 800 coins and all bearing the date 1879, for government officials. But the coin never was approved for regular full-scale production, according to Stack’s Bowers Galleries.

“The Stella represents an attempt to integrate the world’s money as one,” Brian Kendrella, president of Stack’s Bowers Galleries, said in a statement. “We still haven’t been able to do this even today but this coin represents the closest we likely ever came.”

The coin offered for sale next month features the Flowing Hair design. A similar example sold for $411,250 in June 2012, and another for $384,000 in March 2018, both at Stack’s Bowers Galleries auction in Baltimore. Those two were finer graded, though.
description: The denomination from 1879 was intended to be a universal currency, but didn’t go into full production
